title: 104_hr1110
content: The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to set maximum spending amounts for fiscal years 1996 to 2002, ranging from $1,562 billion to $1,760 billion in outlays. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to enforce maximum spending limits through sequestration to reduce total Federal spending to permissible levels as set forth in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to reduce Federal spending by reallocating outlay reductions from defense and non-defense accounts. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a Look-Back Sequester provision, where the Director of OMB determines if spending will exceed the maximum amount for the fiscal year and implements a preliminary sequester on July 1 to eliminate the excess. Any budget authority sequestered on July 1 is permanently canceled. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a Look-Back Sequester provision with a zero margin for determining sequesters. Sequestration procedures from subsections (b), (c), and (d) apply, and reports under section 254 are updated to reflect total spending sequestration. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a Look-Back Sequester provision with a zero margin for determining sequesters. Reports under section 254 for the budget year must include estimates for reductions required from defense and non-defense accounts, sequestration percentages, and necessary reductions in both account types. Additionally, subsection (g)(3) is updated to replace "Deficit" with "Total Spending" in the side heading and text. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to replace "deficit" with "total spending" in various sections, including the item relating to section 253. The amendment also changes "Enforcing deficit targets" to "Enforcing maximum spending limits" in the Table of Contents. SEC. 3. TOTAL SPENDING POINT OF ORDER. Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to establish a point of order against any legislation that would exceed the maximum permissible total spending amount for a fiscal year. Waiver or suspension of this point of order requires a three-fifths majority vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate.
